citeinfo.origin: Minerals Information Team, U.S. Geological Survey
citeinfo.title: Crushed Stone Operations, New York State, 1998

descript.abstract: This data set includes crushed stone operations in the United States. These data were obtained from information reported voluntarily to the USGS by the aggregate producing companies. The data represent commodities covered by the Minerals Information Team (MIT) of the U.S. Geological Survey, and the operations are those considered active in 1998 with production greater than 30,000 tons and surveyed by the MIT.
descript.purpose: These data are intended for the geographic display and analysis at the national level, and for large regional areas. The data should be displayed and analyzed at scales appropriate for 1:2,000,000-scale data. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.
descript.supplinf: Additional minerals operations information can be obtained from the U.S. Geological Survey Minerals Information web page at <http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/>.

idinfo.useconst: None. Acknowledgment of the National Atlas of the United States of America would be appreciated in products derived from these data.
idinfo.datacred: The following USGS scientists contributed to this data set: Wallace Bolen, Matthew Brady, Susan Copeland, Cheryl Crawford, Roxanne DeLong, Cara Doud, Gabe Durand, Patricia Egger, Jennifer James, Brian Jaskula, Lucy McCartan, Nicholas Muniz, Feri Naghdi, Lloyd Southam, Robyn Tapper, and Valentin Tepordei.
idinfo.native: These data are presently stored in grid format, ESRI Arc/INFO version 7.2.1 running under SunOS 5.6.

dataqual.logic: No tests for logical consistency were performed on this data set.
dataqual.complete: This category includes only U.S. aggregate operations covered by the Minerals Information Team of the U.S. Geological Survey and considered currently active in 1998.

procstep.procdesc: AMIS contains both proprietary and nonproprietary information. For each commodity, the Minerals Information Team (MIT) extracted from AMIS the nonproprietary information useful for this application, and placed this information in a separate data base. The MIT determined latitude and longitude for each mineral operation from at least one of the following sources: Delorme Street Atlas software (Searches performed on addresses.) <http://www.yahoo.com/> (Searches performed on company or operation name.) <http://www.superpages.com/> (Searches performed on company or mine id.) <http://www.msha.gov/> (Searches performed on company or operation name.) Whenever possible the locational information was checked for accuracy. The resulting database file was loaded to ArcView and converted to ESRI Shapefile format. The National Atlas staff converted the shape file to an Arc/INFO coverage and then to NAD83. The National Atlas staff also added the State-fips code and converted the full State name to the two-character code. Several coordinate values were corrected so that point locations fell in the correct State. The result was then converted back to shapefile format.

enttyp.enttypd: Facilities that extract, process, and (or) distribute crushed stone for construction.
enttyp.enttypds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

attr.attrdef: The representation of the entity in the data.
The size of the shape in coverage units.
The perimeter of the shape in coverage units.
The name of the company which operates the facility.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

attrdomv.udom: There is no predefined set of valid company names.

attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

attrdomv.udom: There is no predefined set of valid operation names.

attr.attrdef: The county or county equivalent in which the facility is located.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

codesetd.codesetn: Counties and Equivalent Entities of the United States, Its Possessions, and Associated Areas, FIPS 6-4, 1990.
codesetd.codesets: U.S. Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology

attr.attrdef: The 2-letter code for the State in which the facility is located.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

codesetd.codesetn: Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas, FIPS 5-2, 1987.
codesetd.codesets: U.S. Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology

attr.attrdef: The 5-digit FIPS code for the State and county in which the facility is located. The first two digits are the State code, and the last three digits are the county code.

codesetd.codesetn: Counties and Equivalent Entities of the United States, Its Possessions, and Associated Areas (Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 6-4): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.

attr.attrdef: The two-digit code for the State in which the facility is located.

codesetd.codesetn: Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of the United States, and Associated Areas; (Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.

attr.attrdef: Angular distance measured on a meridian north or south from the equator.
attr.attrdefs: Department of Commerce, 1992, Spatial Data Transfer Standard.

attr.attrdef: Angular distance between the plane of a meridian east or west from the plane of the meridian of Greenwich.
attr.attrdefs: Department of Commerce, 1992, Spatial Data Transfer Standard.

attr.attrdef: The type of crushed stone operation.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

edom.edomvd: The facility is a crushed stone operation other than a dredge, portable crusher, sale yard/distribution site, or underground mine.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

edom.edomvd: Large floating machinery equipped with excavating devices (scooping or suction) used for underwater mining.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

edom.edomvd: A rock crushing device that can be moved within one quarry or between two or more quarries.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

edom.edomvd: A location where aggregates are being shipped from mining sites, usually by rail, for sale or distribution to highly populated areas.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

edom.edomvd: A crushed stone operation, where mining occurs under the ground surface.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

attr.attrdef: The mineral(s) produced or processed by the facility.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey, Minerals Information Team

distinfo.distliab: Cornell University provides these geographic data "as is". Cornell University makes no guarantee or warranty concerning the accuracy of information contained in the geographic data. Cornell University further makes no warranty either expressed or implied, regarding the condition of the product or its fitness for any particular purpose. The burden for determining fitness for use lies entirely with the user. Although these files have been processed successfully on computers at Cornell University, no warranty is made by Cornell University regarding the use of these data on any other system, nor does the fact of distribution constitute or imply any such warranty.
